title: 113_s1417
content: The "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2013" includes provisions for improved newborn and child screening, evaluating program effectiveness, establishing advisory committees, creating a clearinghouse of information, ensuring laboratory quality, coordinating interagency efforts, developing a national contingency plan, funding research programs, and authorizing appropriations and reports to Congress. Improved newborn and child screening for heritable disorders is mandated by the "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2013." Section 1109 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include screening, counseling, and training for heritable disorders in newborns and children. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include screening, counseling, and training for heritable disorders in newborns and children, as well as improving the timely collection, delivery, receipt, and screening of specimens for diagnosis. Additionally, there is a focus on evaluating the effectiveness of newborn and child screening and follow-up programs. Section 1110 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include follow-up in child screening, emphasizing timely screening, follow-up, treatment, counseling, testing, and assessing health outcomes for children through adolescence. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include methods for improving quality in the diagnosis, treatment, and management of heritable disorders, as well as best practices for timely collection and diagnosis of newborn screening specimens. Subsection (d) relating to authorization of appropriations is struck. SEC. 4. ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HERITABLE DISORDERS IN NEWBORNS AND CHILDREN. Section 1111 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to provide technical assistance for nominations to the uniform screening panel, including cost considerations. The amendment to Section 1111 of the Public Health Service Act includes provisions for achieving best practices in rapid diagnosis and appropriate treatment, providing information on cost and incidence, and ensuring timely collection and screening of specimens for heritable disorders in newborns. The amendment to Section 1111 of the Public Health Service Act aims to improve rapid diagnosis and treatment, cost and incidence information, and timely screening for heritable disorders in newborns. The amendment also includes changes to the timeline for the Secretary to adopt or reject recommendations, with a notification requirement if unable to comply within 120 days. The amendment to Section 1111 of the Public Health Service Act includes changes to the timeline for the Secretary to adopt or reject recommendations, with a notification requirement if unable to comply within 120 days. It also sets a deadline for the Advisory Committee to review and vote on nominated conditions within 9 months. The Advisory Committee is required to meet at least 4 times each calendar year. The amendment to Section 1111 of the Public Health Service Act sets deadlines for the Advisory Committee to review nominated conditions and requires at least 4 meetings per calendar year. It also updates references to the "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Act of 2008" to the "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2013." SEC. 5. CLEARINGHOUSE OF NEWBORN SCREENING INFORMATION. Section 1112 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include maintaining information on screening conditions in each state and disseminating evidence-based guidelines for newborn screening. In Section 1112 of the Public Health Service Act, amendments include updating the title to the "Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2013" and modifying activities related to the clearinghouse. Subsection (d) regarding authorization of appropriations is removed. SEC. 6. LABORATORY QUALITY AND SURVEILLANCE. Section 1113 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include "surveillance" in the section heading and make adjustments to subsection (a) regarding newborn screening tests. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include surveillance activities for newborn screening, allowing for coordination and data sharing with state-based monitoring programs. SEC. 7 amends Section 1114 of the Public Health Service Act to include the Administrator of the Health Resources and Services Administration, the Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, and the Commissioner of Food and Drugs in the Interagency Coordinating Committee on Newborn and Child Screening. It also removes subsection (e) related to authorization of appropriations. SEC. 8 adds a requirement to update the National Contingency Plan for Newborn Screening as needed and at least every five years. SEC. 9 establishes the Hunter Kelly Research Program. SEC. 9 of the Public Health Service Act establishes the Hunter Kelly Research Program to provide research findings and data for newborn conditions under review by the Advisory Committee on Heritable Disorders in Newborns and Children, and to conduct pilot studies on recommended conditions for nationwide implementation. SEC. 10 authorizes appropriations for newborn screening programs and activities, allocating funds for various sections for fiscal years 2014 through 2018. SEC. 11 requires reports to Congress. The GAO Report on Timeliness of Newborn Screening, required by the Act, will analyze the timeliness of screening for heritable disorders in newborns, including time elapsed from birth to specimen collection, specimen collection to laboratory receipt, receipt to reporting, and reporting to follow-up testing. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to submit a report to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor and Pensions of the Senate within 1 year of the enactment of the Newborn Screening Saves Lives Reauthorization Act of 2013. The report should include an analysis of guidelines and recommendations for maintaining a timely newborn screening system, as well as identifying barriers and providing recommendations to address them. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to the Senate and House committees every 2 years on newborn screening and screening for heritable disorders. The report should detail ongoing activities and expenditures related to sections of the Public Health Service Act. The Senate passed the bill on January 29, 2014, as attested by Nancy Erickson, Secretary.
